Modular prompt scripting. Finally.

Chain-of-thought, designed by you. Turn your markdown into context modules.

code-review.mld
@import [roles, tasks] from [prompts.mld] @text arch = @embed [README.md # Architecture] @text standards = @embed [README.md # Code Standards] @text diff = @run [git diff | cat] @text prompt = [[ Read our docs: {{arch}} {{standards}} Latest changes: {{diff}} Your task: {{tasks.codereview}} ]] @run [oneshot {{prompt}} --system {{roles.architect}}] ---
npm install -g meld oneshot

what is prompt scripting?

If you've experienced the pain,
you know what you need it to be.

Tired of repeating yourself

“I'd do a lot more with LLMs if constantly assembling and re-assembling context wasn't such a chore.”

Tired of wrong tools for the job

“I just want to script LLMs. Don't give me a kitchen sink 'agentic framework' or a magic black box. Give me a unix pipe.”

And if you've seen the possibility,
you know what you want it to be.

Embed LLM context in your docs and treat markdown sections as modules you can import

README.md
# TypeBlorp
              
## Overview 

TypeBlorp is lightweight state management library built with TypeScript, with a unidirectional data flow pattern combined  with observer-based pub/sub architecture.

Here's the structure of the codebase:
@run [tree --gitignore]

@embed [$./docs/ARCHITECTURE.md] as ## Architecture
@embed [$./docs/STANDARDS.md] as ## Code Standards

Chain requests like shell commands

test-plan.mld
@text tests = @run [npm test]

@text res = @run [oneshot "What's broken here? {{tests}}"]

@run [oneshot "Make a plan to fix {{res}}"]

---

"Here's a plan to fix the failing tests."

Imports, templating, command creation

imports.mld
@text docs = @embed [README.md]
              
@data role = {
    "architect": "You are a software architect.",
    "security": "You are a security engineer.",
    "ux": "You are a ux designer."
    "pm": "You are a project manager."
}

@data task = {
    "archrev": "What's the architecture's biggest flaw?",
    "uxrev": "Review the UX of this code",
    "secrev": "Review this code for vulnerabilities",
    "roadmap": "Create a roadmap based on highest priority"
}

>> recursively concatenate paths wrapped in xml tags
@define codecat(dir) = @run [find {{dir}} -type f -exec sh -c 'echo "<$(realpath --relative-to={{dir}} {})>"; cat {}; echo "{{dir}} {})>"' \;]

@define $ask(context, role, task) = @run [oneshot 
  --context {{context}}
  --instructions {{task}}
  --system {{role}}
]
plan.mld
@import [imports.mld]

@path services = "$./src/services"
@text code = @run $codecat($services)

@text context = [[
  Read our docs: {{docs}}
  Review our code: {{code}}
]]

@text arch_review = @run $ask({{context}}, {{role.architect}}, {{task.code_review}})
@text ux_review   = @run $ask({{context}}, {{role.ux}}, {{task.ux_review}})
@text sec_review  = @run $ask({{context}}, {{role.security}}, {{task.sec_review}})

@text pm_review = [[
  Here's the team's input on our priorities:
  - Architect review: {{arch_review}}
  - UX review: {{ux_review}}
  - Security review: {{sec_review}}
  Your task: {{task.pmrev}}
]]

@run $ask({{context}}, {{role.pm}}, {{pm_review}})
